title: Commercial property confidence slumps after post-election surge
text:
The main issues respondents said the federal government needed to address were cities and infrastructure delivery, housing supply and affordability, and energy, emissions and the environment.

"Growing concerns about national economic growth are weighing on sentiment in the property industry, with a sharp drop in sentiment over the last quarter,” said Property Council of Australia chief executive Ken Morrison said.

“The survey underscores the importance of some clear signals from policy-makers on measures which will stimulate investment and spending and underpin confidence for the future."

SA in freefall

Confidence dropped most significantly in South Australia, where the benchmark measure slumped by 43 index points, the biggest quarterly fall of any state or territory in the survey’s history.

Sentiment in the central state has gone from the highest confidence rating in the country to the lowest, in just one quarter, due to land tax changes the state government announced in its June budget that would prevent sophisticated investors from using complex structures to avoid land tax.

Advertisement

Even though the state Liberal government has brought forward a proposal to cut the top rate of land tax to 2.4 per cent from 3.7 per cent, some developers have hired former Liberal defence minister Christopher Pyne to lobby against the planned abolition of so-called aggregation benefits – a situation Rich List developer Con Makris called a "disgrace".

While sentiment about capital growth weakened nationally across the office, industrial, retirement living and hotel sectors, the largest decline came in retail property.

Retail capital growth expectations continued to fall, declining by a further nine index points and remaining in negative territory for the sixth consecutive quarter, the survey showed.

In contrast to commercial property, sentiment around residential property picked up, largely due to sentiment that securing financing had become easier.

Home lending jumped 5.1 per cent in July, marking its biggest monthly gain in four years, Australian Bureau of Statistics figures last month showed.

"That access to credit was really driving the weakness in the residential market. That improvement is very significant," Ms Emmett said.

"It is consistent with the fact that we’re not just seeing this turnaround in price, but seeing a pick-up in housing finance. It does look as if finance is becoming a little bit easier to get."

The improving residential sentiment also meant that separate figures earlier this week showing a 1.1 per cent decline in new dwelling approvals may be overstating the true picture. This, combined with the post-election rise in housing prices and auction clearance rates, could stimulate new housing, she said.

"It suggests the outlook is a bit more promising than the building approvals numbers are pointing to," Ms Emmett said.

"Hopefully that will flow into the construction sector."
description: But a rise in residential sentiment suggests fears about housing supply may be overblown.
